busy.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: if you are busy, you are working hard and have a lot of things to do
busy.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: She’s busy now – can you phone later?
There were lots of activities to keep the kids busy.
Mr Haynes is busy with a customer at the moment.
Rachel’s busy studying for her exams.
busy.translation[0].definitions[0].note_: I’m very busy with work at the moment
busy.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: a busy period of time is full of work or other activities
busy.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: December is the busiest time of year for shops.
He took time out of his busy schedule to visit us.
busy.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: a busy place is very full of people or vehicles and movement
busy.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: We live on a very busy road.
busy.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: if a telephone you are calling is busy, it makes a repeated sound to tell you that the person you are calling is talking on their telephone
busy.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: I called Sonya, but her line was busy.
I keep getting a busy signal.
busy.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: a pattern or design that is busy is too full of small details – used to show disapproval
busy.translation[0].note_box[0].sections: if you are busy, you have a lot of things you need to do
Sorry I haven’t called you, but I’ve been really busy.
a busy housewife
Angela was becoming more and more unhappy, but her husband was too busy to notice.
Not now Stephen, I’m busy.
Alex is busy studying for his exams.
rushed/run off your feet
very busy and in a hurry, because you have too many things to do
We’ve been absolutely rushed off our feet getting ready for our son’s birthday party.
snowed under
so busy that you can hardly deal with all the work you have to do
I can’t stop for lunch today – I’m completely snowed under.
We’ve been snowed under with applications for the job.
up to your ears/neck in something
extremely busy because you have a lot of work to deal with
Teachers say they are up to their ears in paperwork and don’t have enough time for teaching.
tied up
busy in your job, so that you cannot do anything else
I’m sorry, but he’s tied up at the moment. Could you call back later?
I can’t see you tomorrow: I’m tied up all day.
have a lot to do
to have to do a lot of things, so that you need to hurry or work hard
Let’s get started – we have a lot to do.
have a lot on
to be busy, especially because you have arranged to do a lot of things during a particular period
I’ve got a lot on this weekend.
He says he’ll try and see you as soon as possible, but he has a lot going on this afternoon.
use this about times when you have a lot of things you need to do
We have a busy day ahead of us tomorrow.
July and August are our busiest times.
hectic
a hectic time or situation is extremely busy, so that you are always in a hurry and often feel excited or worried
It was really hectic at work today.
The band had a hectic recording schedule.
the rush hour
the time in the morning and evening when a lot of people are travelling to or from work
The buses are so crowded during the rush hour you never get a seat.
In most British cities the rush hour does not start until about 8 o’clock.
busy.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: a telephone that is busy is being used
busy.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: someone who is busy is working and is not available
busy.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: Mr Bullon is busy right now - can you phone back after lunch?
I’ve been busy with customers all morning
busy.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: a busy period is full of work
busy.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: Christmas is one of Oxford Street’s busiest times of the year.
